**Does the bug happen if you start with `--temp-basedir`?**:

https://users.rust-lang.org/ seems to be unsupported in qutebrowser. It runs on https://github.com/discourse/discourse as far as I know. Is this expected behaviour?

commits.message:
fix non 6.6 resource entry lookup

We need to pass objects, not indexes. Test with Qt 6.5 to exercise this
path.

run pakjoy for real at application boot

It all just works!

Changes from the `__main__` implementation down below:

* copy the whole resources directory instead of just the one file:
  looking at the implementation around QTWEBENGINE_RESOURCES_PATH it
  uses the main resources file to find the one directory and then loads
  the other resources from that dir. So I'm assuming it was crashing
  because it couldn't find the other resources. Stack trace was:

    #1  0x00007fffe95f1dca in content::ContentMainRunnerImpl::Initialize(content::ContentMainParams) ()
       from /usr/local/Qt-6.6.0/lib/libQt6WebEngineCore.so.6
    #2  0x00007fffe628cf09 in QtWebEngineCore::WebEngineContext::WebEngineContext() ()
       from /usr/local/Qt-6.6.0/lib/libQt6WebEngineCore.so.6
    #3  0x00007fffe628dfa4 in QtWebEngineCore::WebEngineContext::current() ()
       from /usr/local/Qt-6.6.0/lib/libQt6WebEngineCore.so.6
    #4  0x00000210b845c780 in ?? ()
    #5  0x00000210b845c780 in ?? ()
    #6  0x00007fffffffd480 in ?? ()
    #7  0x00007fffe62391bb in QtWebEngineCore::ProfileAdapter::ProfileAdapter(QString const&) ()
       from /usr/local/Qt-6.6.0/lib/libQt6WebEngineCore.so.6

* write stuff to our cache dir, not tmp ;)

I haven't actually checked this fixes an affected version of Qt (need to
rebuild or get from riverbank pypi). But I unpacked the pak file and it
has the right fake URL in it.

issue.title: Switching to Qt 6 by default
issue.body:
*(Continuation of #5395 because that was getting rather big)*

# Current state

On July 22th, 2023, the flip was finally switched to Qt 6 by default. All you need to ensure is what PyQt6 is available, and Qt 6 will be used automatically. If it's not available, you will get a warning shown by qutebrowser.

**All information below is considered historical.**

~~The qt6-v2 branch **has been merged to master** on March 18th, 2023, but with Qt 5 still being the default. See #7628 for details. This issue is now repurposed on what there needs to be done for Qt 6 to be the default Qt wrapper.~~

~~The last fixes for the `qt6-v2` branch with Qt 6 support went in around May 19th. Multiple core developers (and users) have been using it as a daily driver since far longer (late 2021 / early 2022) and all known crashes are fixed, with all tests passing.~~

~~There is still a lot of remaining work, however, on the development side. Due to the [big amount of changes](https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/compare/qt6-v2) (currently 156 commits, 314 files changed, 12,978 additions and 4,094 deletions) it's tricky to integrate this into `master` without breaking lots of existing open PRs. Thus, we'd like to do another round of PR merging before attempting to do so. The current approach also breaks various tooling, by not properly supporting static analysis (#7128, but that will introduce another big code churn), or by not fixing linting issues yet (#1455).~~

~~Bottomline: Feel free to use the `qt6-v2` branch, keep in mind it will be rebased from time to time, and it will still take lots of efforts behind the scenes to get it fully integrated.~~

# How to try

## `mkvenv.py`

- **Take a backup of your qutebrowser data directory** (see `:version`) unless you don't mind losing cookies and such when down-/upgrading. This isn't needed if you use `--temp-basedir` below, but if you forget to do so, your data will get upgraded, and as far as I'm aware, there is no way to read it with Qt 5 after that.
- Clone the git repo, e.g. via `git clone https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser.git`
- `cd qutebrowser`
- ~~Check out the branch using `git checkout qt6-v2`~~
- Create a new separate environment via `python3 scripts/mkvenv.py --venv-dir .venv-qt6 --pyqt-version 6.3`
- Set `QUTE_QT_WRAPPER=PyQt6` somewhere in the environment
- Run `.venv-qt6/bin/qutebrowser --temp-basedir` and verify via `:version` that you're indeed on Qt 6

## Archlinux

[qutebrowser-qt6-git](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/qutebrowser-qt6-git) is available in the AUR.

## Windows / macOS

Built as part of the [nightly builds](https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/actions/workflows/nightly.yml) on CI. Click on the most recent passing build, then find the `qt6` builds under "Artifacts". Note that you will need to be logged in with a GitHub account to download.

**Note for macOS:** Due to a [PyInstaller issue](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/pull/6903), Chromium's [sandboxing](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/HEAD/docs/design/sandbox_faq.md) is currently disabled **for macOS builds with Qt 6**. This means that there will be no additional layer of protection in case of Chromium security bugs. Thus, it's advised to not use this build in production. Hopefully, this situation [will be resolved before the final 3.0.0 release](https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/issues/7278).

## Flatpak

[Published in the `flathub-beta` repo](https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/issues/5395#issuecomment-1129936579):

> Adding the flathub-beta remote and installing from the beta branch can be done through an application manager (Gnome Software, Discover, ...) or via the command-line.
>
> ```
> $ flatpak remote-add --if-not-exists flathub-beta https://flathub.org/beta-repo/flathub-beta.flatpakrepo
> $ flatpak install flathub-beta org.qutebrowser.qutebrowser//beta
> ```

# Remaining issues

- [x] Flickering rectangles with AMD graphics: #7398 (seems to be fixed in Qt 6.4)
- [x] Mouse wheel sometimes stops working for me: #7523 (known upsteam Qt issue)
- [x] favicons don't show for some tabs sometimes ~~(TODO: find reproducer, going to eg https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/commits/qt6-test and clicking on one of the commits seems to lose the favicon) *([from @toofar](https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/issues/5395#issuecomment-1003259843), haven't checked if it's still an issue)*~~ see https://github.com/qutebrowser/qutebrowser/issues/7202#issuecomment-1142021295
- [x] Wrong MPRIS name: #7431


# TODOs

- [x] Get macOS builds to work
- [x] ~~Look at remaining API changes and new features (comment below)~~ moved to #7756
- [x] Look at remaining `FIXME:qt6` comments
- [x] Make sure qutebrowser has enough feedback (e.g. logging?) about which Qt wrappers it uses and why
- [x] ~~Maybe investigate storing the Qt wrapper to use in a config file so that we don't unexpectedly switch (and destroy data?) if one is unavailable~~
- [ ] Decide what to do about test coverage (switch to Qt 6? Combine?)
- [x] ~~Probably merge some PRs while waiting for more feedback and to avoid crazy conflicts with the next steps~~ moved to v4
- [x] ~~Integrate #7128 if we didn't find a way to make static analysis work otherwise~~ see #7370 and linked discussion and issue
- [x] ~~Adopt `black` (#1455) so that we pass "normal" linting again and don't have crazy long lines~~ moved to v4
- [x] ~~Look at adopting PySide6 again~~ not a priority at the moment
- [x] Check if we can revert 3c4d51a03cefb010e57c1e85c53e70bb77de8387
- [x] Potentially start cherry-picking some stuff to master
- [ ] Figure out why our way of blocking back/forward mouse button presses broke
- [x] Perhaps introduce a Qt 5 warning to get people to switch over

comment.body: Perhaps this can be unpinned now that Qute 3 / QT 6 are the default.

issue.title: qutebrowser crashes with qt6-webengine 6.6.0
issue.body:
**Version info**:
qutebrowser v3.0.0
Git commit: 
Backend: QtWebEngine 6.5.3, based on Chromium 108.0.5359.220 (from api)
Qt: 6.5.3 (compiled 6.5.1)

CPython: 3.11.5
PyQt: 6.5.1

Qt wrapper info:
  PyQt6: success
  PyQt5: not imported
  -> selected: PyQt6 (via autoselect)

colorama: no
jinja2: 3.1.2
pygments: 2.16.1
yaml: 6.0.1
adblock: no
objc: no
PyQt6.QtWebEngineCore: 6.5.0
PyQt6.sip: 6.7.9
pdf.js: 3.11.174 (/usr/share/pdf.js/build/pdf.js)
sqlite: 3.43.2
QtNetwork SSL: OpenSSL 3.1.3 19 Sep 2023

**Does the bug happen if you start with `--temp-basedir`?**:

yes.

**Description**

One or more of the upgrades among:
```
qt6-base 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-declarative 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-positioning 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-svg 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-translations 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webchannel 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webengine 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
python-pyqt6 6.5.1 -> 6.5.2
python-pyqt6-sip 13.5.1 -> 13.5.2
```

causes qutebrowser to crash at the first session auto-save interval on every startup.

i am unclear on which package upgrade is the culprit, but I would assume it's an issue in the qt6 group of upgrades to 6.6.0 rather than something with the python bindings. I was able to obtain a stack trace earlier, btu I do not have it currently and can update the bug report with one later.

**How to reproduce**
<!-- Link to the affected site, or steps to reproduce the issue (if possible/applicable). -->
Install the 6.6.0 suite of qt6 packages.

Personally I did this on archlinux, where the upgrade happened automatically this morning when I synced my packages.

issue.title: Crash when loading Google meeting

issue.title: qutebrowser crashes with qt6-webengine 6.6.0
issue.body:
**Version info**:
qutebrowser v3.0.0
Git commit: 
Backend: QtWebEngine 6.5.3, based on Chromium 108.0.5359.220 (from api)
Qt: 6.5.3 (compiled 6.5.1)

CPython: 3.11.5
PyQt: 6.5.1

Qt wrapper info:
  PyQt6: success
  PyQt5: not imported
  -> selected: PyQt6 (via autoselect)

colorama: no
jinja2: 3.1.2
pygments: 2.16.1
yaml: 6.0.1
adblock: no
objc: no
PyQt6.QtWebEngineCore: 6.5.0
PyQt6.sip: 6.7.9
pdf.js: 3.11.174 (/usr/share/pdf.js/build/pdf.js)
sqlite: 3.43.2
QtNetwork SSL: OpenSSL 3.1.3 19 Sep 2023

**Does the bug happen if you start with `--temp-basedir`?**:

yes.

**Description**

One or more of the upgrades among:
```
qt6-base 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-declarative 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-positioning 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-svg 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-translations 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webchannel 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webengine 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
python-pyqt6 6.5.1 -> 6.5.2
python-pyqt6-sip 13.5.1 -> 13.5.2
```

causes qutebrowser to crash at the first session auto-save interval on every startup.

i am unclear on which package upgrade is the culprit, but I would assume it's an issue in the qt6 group of upgrades to 6.6.0 rather than something with the python bindings. I was able to obtain a stack trace earlier, btu I do not have it currently and can update the bug report with one later.

**How to reproduce**
<!-- Link to the affected site, or steps to reproduce the issue (if possible/applicable). -->
Install the 6.6.0 suite of qt6 packages.

Personally I did this on archlinux, where the upgrade happened automatically this morning when I synced my packages.

comment.body:
> @fluffywaffles to ensure you're seeing the same issue @welps is, could you please try to get a stack trace with debug symbols? To do so:
> 
> * Make sure you have `gdb` installed.
> * Set up [Debuginfod](https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Debuginfod) - doing a `export DEBUGINFOD_URLS="https://debuginfod.archlinux.org/"` should actually be enough.
> * Run `coredumpctl gdb 7960`
> * Once you get a `(gdb)` prompt (might take a bit of time and download some data), run `bt` and show the output here.

`7960` was garbage collected during a restart or something; I reproduced the issue and followed the above steps on an equivalent crash that shows the same characteristics.

<details>

issue.title: qutebrowser crashes with qt6-webengine 6.6.0
issue.body:
**Version info**:
qutebrowser v3.0.0
Git commit: 
Backend: QtWebEngine 6.5.3, based on Chromium 108.0.5359.220 (from api)
Qt: 6.5.3 (compiled 6.5.1)

CPython: 3.11.5
PyQt: 6.5.1

Qt wrapper info:
  PyQt6: success
  PyQt5: not imported
  -> selected: PyQt6 (via autoselect)

colorama: no
jinja2: 3.1.2
pygments: 2.16.1
yaml: 6.0.1
adblock: no
objc: no
PyQt6.QtWebEngineCore: 6.5.0
PyQt6.sip: 6.7.9
pdf.js: 3.11.174 (/usr/share/pdf.js/build/pdf.js)
sqlite: 3.43.2
QtNetwork SSL: OpenSSL 3.1.3 19 Sep 2023

**Does the bug happen if you start with `--temp-basedir`?**:

yes.

**Description**

One or more of the upgrades among:
```
qt6-base 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-declarative 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-positioning 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-svg 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-translations 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webchannel 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
qt6-webengine 6.5.3 -> 6.6.0
python-pyqt6 6.5.1 -> 6.5.2
python-pyqt6-sip 13.5.1 -> 13.5.2
```

causes qutebrowser to crash at the first session auto-save interval on every startup.

i am unclear on which package upgrade is the culprit, but I would assume it's an issue in the qt6 group of upgrades to 6.6.0 rather than something with the python bindings. I was able to obtain a stack trace earlier, btu I do not have it currently and can update the bug report with one later.

**How to reproduce**

issue.title: Lazy tab loading

labels.name: priority: 1 - middle
labels.description: Issues which should be done at some point, but aren't that important.

issue.body:
At some point with session support we also should have lazy tab loading, i.e. only loading tabs when they are focused.

---

**In December 2017, a `session.lazy_restore` option was added, which at least allows this for sessions.**

issue.title: Two finger scrolling on a touchpad triggers a secondary zoom occasionally
issue.body:
**Version info**:
qutebrowser v3.0.0
Git commit: 
Backend: QtWebEngine 6.5.3, based on Chromium 108.0.5359.220 (from api)
Qt: 6.5.3

CPython: 3.10.12
PyQt: 6.5.2

Qt wrapper info:
  PyQt6: success
  PyQt5: not imported
  -> selected: PyQt6 (via autoselect)

colorama: no
jinja2: 3.1.2
pygments: 2.15.1
yaml: 6.0.1
adblock: 0.6.0
objc: no
PyQt6.QtWebEngineCore: 6.5.0
PyQt6.sip: 6.7.10
pdf.js: 3.9.179 (/nix/store/wina0bcmiw1z921hb4hijfr18ajh2sy6-source/build/pdf.js)
sqlite: 3.43.1
QtNetwork SSL: OpenSSL 3.0.10 1 Aug 2023

Style: QFusionStyle
Platform plugin: xcb
OpenGL: Intel, 4.2 (Compatibility Profile) Mesa 23.0.3
Platform: Linux-6.1.56-x86_64-with-glibc2.37, 64bit
Linux distribution: NixOS 23.05 (Stoat) (nixos)

**Does the bug happen if you start with `--temp-basedir`?**:
No

**Description**
When scrolling with two fingers on a touchpad I will occasionally notice web pages tend to zoom in in a fashion that is completely separate from the in-browser zoom level (i.e., changing my zoom will not undo the zoom). Tabs with the secondary zoom will retain the zoom when closed. Restarting the browser with :restart will resolve the issue. New clean tabs (not cloned) will not have this secondary zoom.

**How to reproduce**
 I'm not entirely sure what specific touchpad interactions cause it, but I definitely notice it when scrolling up and down a lot, it will only occur occasionally, but I must be scrolling for it to happen. I am not clicking on anything else on the keyboard, and I've ruled out any stuck keyboard keys. This started happening after the PyQt6 upgrade.
